question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
Let \emph{P} be a real symmetric \emph{n x n} matrix such that
\emph{P\textsuperscript{2} = P}. Also let \emph{R = I\textsubscript{n} -
2P} be the matrix that reflects a vector across a plane.

\textbf{(a)} Show that \emph{R} is an orthogonal matrix and that
\emph{R\textsuperscript{2} = I\textsubscript{n}}.
sols:
$R^{T}R = (I-2P)^{T}(I-2P) = (I^{T} - 2P^{T})(I - 2P)$

Now since \emph{P} is real symmetrical $P^{T} = P$

Also the transpose of the identity matrix, \emph{I} is itself

So expanding

$(I^{T} - 2P^{T})(I - 2P) 
= I^{T}I - 2PI^{T} - 2P^{T}I -4P^{T}P = I^2 + 4P - 4P^2$

As $P = P^2$ and $I^2 = I$

$R^{T}R = I$

Similarily for

$RR^T= I = (I-2P)(I-2P)^{T} = (I - 2P)(I^{T} - 2P^{T})$
$= II^{T} -2PI^{T} -2IP^T +4P^{2}I^T = I^2 -2P -2P^T +4 P^2 = I - 4P +4P = I$
